body: Is that possible ? I've also added commits for `package-info` and integration-test.

This PR fixes some issues in the javadoc, in particular invalid links and references to stuff that no longer applies, as well as:
- Useless semicolon use
- Overcomplicated boolean expressions
- Removes unneeded java keywords (e.g. final on private method, return ; in void).
- Style fixes for Filter<T>

I did not create a JIRA for this since this is a small fix, but please tell me in case I must create one.
R: @dhalperi
R: @jbonofre

Thanks for the initial review! The Combine transform is still commented out because the runner does not yet correctly determine whether a combine is possible. This depends on whether the window function can merge and on whether we have side inputs. I still have to fix that for this PR. Same goes for the non-deterministic-key-coder portions.

LGTM.

I will squash the commits and amend the message to link to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-475.
CC: @kennknowles @bjchambers for discussion of bytecode gen
Noting that Jenkins took 52 minutes, which is noticeably slower, though sample size is one. Much harder to discern for Travis. Going to rebase and kick to get another data point.
R: @bjchambers
CC: @aaltay
Interesting. I had thought that nonzero parallelism was the default. Is this not true? It certainly does look like this might have sped Jenkins up a bit, though it might just be usual variance.
R: @dhalperi
PTAL. I think the testing represented by this PR is a good compromise between correctness and performance. I am open to further optimization, etc.

The code seems pretty much good, with just a couple comments. I would expect fairly catastrophic test failure if this hung the runner so there are good assurances.

There are a few places where it gets into fairly deeply nested & chained conditionals that incrementally are fine but might eventually suggest some refactor. No concrete ideas at the moment.
LGTM & I'd ignore Travis failure.
Though you wrote "WIP" I'd merge ASAP and revise in follow-ups if needed.
Failing fast is amazing.
LGTM, self-merge (once green)

LGTM. Will merge when green.

It is rather mechanical but large-scale. I'd love to get it in when things get green so that further changes can be incremental.
Also: everything will be ported _back_ to `DoFn` so there is little use in fixing grammar, etc.

LGTM (but also get committer approval)

Added two fixes:
1. The new `DoFn` did not propagate `getAllowedTimestampSkew`. It is a problematic method, but we haven't got an immediate solution anyhow.
2. `ParDo` just looked like it forgot to use the class that it got from `DoFnReflector`

Interesting note from [Travis' documentation on caching](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/caching/#Things-not-to-cache):

> The caches purpose is to make installing language-specific dependencies easy and fast, so everything related to tools like Bundler, pip, Composer, npm, Gradle, Maven, is what should go into the cache.
> 
> Large files that are quick to install but slow to download do not benefit from caching, as they take as long to download from the cache as from the original source:
> 
> Android SDKs
> Debian packages
> JDK packages
> Compiled binaries

I would expect Maven dependencies to be in the "quick to install but slow to download" category, although the explicitly mention Maven above.

I'm worried about the potential to depend on a previously-built beam artifact. Could we use something like [`dependency:purge-local-repository`](http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-dependency-plugin/examples/purging-local-repository.html) to clear beam artifacts before/after the build?

```
mvn dependency:purge-local-repository -Dinclude=org.apache.beam -DresolutionFuzziness=groupId
```

Running before the build would protect us from using stale jars; running afterwards would ensure we're not caching more than we need to.
LGTM

Their verbiage seems to equivocate. We are very much caching "everything related to tools like... Maven" but they are almost entirely compiled binaries. But perhaps jars are in-between.

Our point of failure seems to be transient request timeouts, so my thinking is that this will help in the following ways, beyond what #792 will do:
- We'll be making one large request instead of dozens (hundreds?) so we'll remove the statistical certainty of a timeout.
- We'll be downloading from S3, so whatever issue it is that we are hitting will not occur if it is at least partially to do with the server.

That said, it is just an attempt, to see what the end-to-end timing change is.

I do believe our use of `-U` aka `--update-snapshots` should protect us from stale snapshots.

I would be very happy to have another layer of protection. I've tried a number of incantations of the `purge-local-repository` command, trying out `-DreResolve=false` and `-DactTransitively=false` and `--snapshotsOnly=true` but they all result in downloading jars from the snapshot repository.

There's always the crude `rm -rf $HOME/.m2/repository/org/apache/beam`.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/6104560/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/6104560)

Changes Unknown when pulling **2efe7617a595b8ac6167db40724d9874afd6df23 on francesperry:master** into *\* on apache:master**.

I wasn't familiar with `mvn -U`; it sounds like that will ensure we don't use stale cached dependencies, but not protect us from using a cached beam jar.

The particular scenario I'm worried about is if a module got built before it's dependencies, it could pull those dependencies from a stale cached build. I mess this up all the time locally by building only specific targets, but it could also happen when maintaining pom.xml files.

I'm also not able to get `dependency:purge-local-repository` to not download jars. I would be in favor of using `rm -rf`.

OK. A brief chat with @dhalperi too, and I've added redundant/idempotent `rm` commands: One to make sure that no matter what we never build with old jars, and separately one before caching to avoid writing the cache.

PTAL. Rebased and fixed up.

Note that using our own settings file also works around travis-ci/travis-ci#4269, wherein containerized Travis builds have a broken `settings.xml`.

The full contents of it:

```
<settings>
  <profiles>
    <profile>
      <id>standard-with-extra-repos</id>
      <activation>
        <activeByDefault>true</activeByDefault>
      </activation>

      <repositories>
        <repository>
          <id>central</id>
          <name>Central Repository</name>
          <url>http://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2</url>
          <releases>
            <enabled>true</enabled>
          </releases>
          <snapshots>
            <enabled>false</enabled>
          </snapshots>
        </repository>

        <repository>
          <id>sonatype</id>
          <name>OSS Sonatype repo (releases)</name>
          <releases>
            <enabled>true</enabled>
            <updatePolicy>always</updatePolicy>
            <checksumPolicy>warn</checksumPolicy>
          </releases>
          <snapshots>
            <enabled>false</enabled>
            <updatePolicy>never</updatePolicy>
            <checksumPolicy>fail</checksumPolicy>
          </snapshots>
          <url>https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/releases/</url>
        </repository>

        <repository>
          <id>sonatype-snapshots</id>
          <name>OSS Sonatype repo (snapshots)</name>
          <releases>
            <enabled>false</enabled>
            <updatePolicy>always</updatePolicy>
            <checksumPolicy>warn</checksumPolicy>
          </releases>
          <snapshots>
            <enabled>true</enabled>
            <updatePolicy>never</updatePolicy>
            <checksumPolicy>fail</checksumPolicy>
          </snapshots>
          <url>https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/snapshots/</url>
        </repository>

        <repository>
          <id>sonatype-apache</id>
          <name>Apache repo (releases)</name>
          <releases>
            <enabled>true</enabled>
            <updatePolicy>always</updatePolicy>
            <checksumPolicy>warn</checksumPolicy>
          </releases>
          <snapshots>
            <enabled>false</enabled>
            <updatePolicy>never</updatePolicy>
            <checksumPolicy>fail</checksumPolicy>
          </snapshots>
          <url>https://repository.apache.org/releases/</url>
        </repository>

        <repository>
          <id>apache-snapshots</id>
          <name>ASF repo (snapshots)</name>
          <releases>
            <enabled>false</enabled>
            <updatePolicy>never</updatePolicy>
            <checksumPolicy>warn</checksumPolicy>
          </releases>
          <snapshots>
            <enabled>true</enabled>
            <updatePolicy>always</updatePolicy>
            <checksumPolicy>fail</checksumPolicy>
          </snapshots>
          <url>https://repository.apache.org/snapshots/</url>
        </repository>

        <repository>
          <id>codehaus-snapshots</id>
          <name>Codehaus (snapshots)</name>
          <releases>
            <enabled>false</enabled>
            <updatePolicy>always</updatePolicy>
            <checksumPolicy>warn</checksumPolicy>
          </releases>
          <snapshots>
            <enabled>true</enabled>
            <updatePolicy>never</updatePolicy>
            <checksumPolicy>fail</checksumPolicy>
          </snapshots>
          <url>https://nexus.codehaus.org/snapshots/</url>
        </repository>
      </repositories>
    </profile>
  </profiles>

  <!-- remove the mirrors for now as VMs are based in the US -->
  <!-- <mirrors>
    <mirror>
      <id>travis-ci-central</id>
      <name>Travis CI Central mirror</name>
      <url>http://maven.mirrors.travis-ci.org/nexus/content/repositories/central/</url>
      <mirrorOf>central</mirrorOf>
    </mirror>

    <mirror>
      <id>travis-ci-sonatype</id>
      <name>Travis CI oss.sonatype.org mirror</name>
      <url>http://maven.mirrors.travis-ci.org/nexus/content/repositories/sonatype/</url>
      <mirrorOf>sonatype</mirrorOf>
    </mirror>

    <mirror>
      <id>travis-ci-sonatype-snapshots</id>
      <name>Travis CI oss.sonatype.org mirror (snapshots)</name>
      <url>http://maven.mirrors.travis-ci.org/nexus/content/repositories/sonatype-snapshots/</url>
      <mirrorOf>sonatype-snapshots</mirrorOf>
    </mirror>

    <mirror>
      <id>travis-ci-apache</id>
      <name>Travis CI repository.apache.org mirror (releases)</name>
      <url>http://maven.mirrors.travis-ci.org/nexus/content/repositories/apache/</url>
      <mirrorOf>apache</mirrorOf>
    </mirror>

    <mirror>
      <id>travis-ci-apache-snapshots</id>
      <name>Travis CI repository.apache.org mirror (snapshots)</name>
      <url>http://maven.mirrors.travis-ci.org/nexus/content/repositories/apache-snapshots/</url>
      <mirrorOf>sonatype-snapshots</mirrorOf>
    </mirror>

    <mirror>
      <id>travis-ci-codehaus-snapshots</id>
      <name>Travis CI Codehaus mirror (snapshots)</name>
      <url>http://maven.mirrors.travis-ci.org/nexus/content/repositories/codehaus-snapshots/</url>
      <mirrorOf>codehaus-snapshots</mirrorOf>
    </mirror>
  </mirrors> -->
</settings>
```

I see nothing that we need to retain.
